topic.title: Guidelines for concept short descriptions
topic.shortdesc: Always use the <shortdesc> element in a concept topic. Omit the <context> element if what you describe in the <shortdesc> element is sufficient. The short description must make sense both as the opening text of the topic and as pop-up text over a related link.

prolog.author: Guidelines owner: Michelle Carey, from Content Workgroup

section.title: Length
section.p: Use one to three sentences or up to 50 words.

section.title: What to say
section.p: Introduce the concept and provide a concise answer to the question "What is this?" and in some cases "Why do I care about this?" If the concept is unfamiliar, you can start with a brief definition. Avoid using the short description to lead in or build up to a topic. The short description paragraph should contain the main point of the conceptual topic. The concept short description should clearly apply to a concept. Avoid turning the concept topic into a task. Do not simply repeat the title.

p.b: Example of an ineffective short description

dlentry.dd: This topic is about crawlers, which are programs that search for information.

section.p: This ineffective short description provides only a vague description. It does not answer why users should care about what crawlers do or how they work.

p.b: Example of an effective short description

dlentry.dd: Crawlers are programs that search for information on the Web, in databases, or in other data sources. The information that the crawlers gather is added to the search engine index. Crawlers must run regularly to ensure that the search engine index is up to date.

section.p: The effective short description provides a more specific definition of crawlers and describes why crawlers are useful to search engine indexes.

section.title: Phrasing
section.p: Do not use sentence fragments. Use complete sentences. Avoid starting short descriptions with phrases such as This topic describes . . . . or This topic is about . . . .

section.title: Examples of effective short descriptions
section.p:
Topic titles are in bold. Short descriptions are in plain text. Highlighting in a short description will not appear in the pop-up text over a related link.
Cube models
A cube model is a DB2 object that describes the data that is related to a collection of measures. The cube model groups relevant dimension objects around a facts object, creating a star schema or snowflake schema.
Search collections
A search collection is a set of data sources that users can search with a single query. A search collection can contain data from Web sites, file systems, and databases. You can build new collections or continue to update existing collections.
Enterprise Bean Deployment tool
The Enterprise Bean Deployment tool helps you generate deployment code for your enterprise beans before you run them on a test server or a production server. You can use this tool from the command line or from WebSphere Studio Application Developer.
Class shapes
In modeling diagrams, a class shape is a graphical element that represents a Java class, a Java interface, or an EJB component. You can use multiple instances of a class shape in one or more diagrams.

section.title: Examples of ineffective short descriptions
section.p:
Topic titles are in bold. Short descriptions are in plain text. Cube models A cube model is a collection of metadata objects.

This short description is a fragment.
Types of spatial indexes Good query performance is related to having efficient indexes defined on the columns of the base tables in a database. The performance of the query is directly related to how quickly values in the column can be found during the query. Queries that use an index can execute more quickly and can provide a significant performance improvement.
This short description does not address the topic title, and it is too long. The topic is about spatial indexes, yet the short description discusses query performance. The writer might be using the short description to lead in or build up to a point. However, the short description should directly state the main point.
Guidelines for writing a program for debugging You can make your programs easier to debug by following these simple guidelines:
Avoid adding a list or table lead-in sentence to a short description. You cannot add an <ol> or <ul> element inside a short description element. If you add a list or table lead-in sentence and then add the list or table to the next available element, the list or table will not be logically associated with the <shortdesc> element. Such a structure is semantically incorrect. You will not be able to reuse the list or table with its lead-in sentence. Also, this short description will not make sense in pop-up text for a related link.
